message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of poor self-esteem, poor appetite, difficulty with concentration, trouble with sleep, and has been experiencing them for the past 3 years. The presence of these symptoms for such a long time and the patient's family history of major depressive disorder suggests Persistent depressive disorder as the most likely diagnosis. The other options are less likely as they either have specific timeframes for symptoms or different symptom profiles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of depression persisting for at least 2 years, which suggests Persistent depressive disorder. The patient’s father’s history also suggests a genetic predisposition to depression. The other options do not fit the patient’s symptoms or history.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been experiencing symptoms for the past 3 years, which suggests Persistent Depressive Disorder. The patient's symptoms of poor self-esteem, hopelessness, poor appetite, and insomnia are common symptoms of Persistent Depressive Disorder. The fact that the patient's father had major depressive disorder and committed suicide also increases the likelihood of a diagnosis of Persistent Depressive Disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms of poor self-esteem and feelings of hopelessness lasting for 3 years suggests Persistent depressive disorder. The patient’s lack of interest in romantic relationships may also be a symptom of this disorder. Cyclothymia is a milder form of bipolar disorder characterized by cycling mood changes, while Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder and Seasonal affective disorder do not fit the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms have occurred for the past 3 years, and she has poor self-esteem, poor appetite, difficulty with concentration, and trouble with sleep. She also has a family history of major depressive disorder. These findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is persistent depressive disorder. None of the other options fit the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms have been present for the past 3 years, indicating persistent depressive disorder. The patient's lack of self-esteem, poor appetite, difficulty with concentration, and trouble with sleep are all common symptoms of depression. The patient's family history of major depressive disorder also increases the likelihood of this diagnosis. None of the other options fit the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of depression lasting for more than 2 years with no periods of remission lasting more than 2 months, which matches the criteria for Persistent Depressive Disorder. The patient’s symptoms do not match those of Cyclothymia, Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder or Seasonal Affective Disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of depression that have been ongoing for 3 years and poor self-esteem. These symptoms suggest persistent depressive disorder. Cyclothymia is a milder form of bipolar disorder and involves distinct periods of hypomania and depression. Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder is a childhood disorder characterized by severe and recurrent temper outbursts. Seasonal affective disorder is a type of depression that occurs during the fall and winter months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has been experiencing symptoms for the past three years, which suggests the diagnosis is not seasonal affective disorder. The symptoms are also not characteristic of cyclothymia or disruptive mood dysregulation disorder. The patient’s history of persistent symptoms and poor self-esteem, as well as her father’s history of major depressive disorder, point towards a diagnosis of persistent depressive disorder. The patient’s physical exam findings also support this diagnosis with her gloomy demeanor and restlessness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has had symptoms for the past 3 years, which is longer than the typical duration of seasonal affective disorder. Cyclothymia has periods of hypomania and depressive symptoms, but there is no history of hypomania in the patient. Disruptive mood dysregulation disorder typically presents in children and includes frequent temper tantrums. Persistent depressive disorder is a chronic form of depression that lasts for at least 2 years, which fits the patient's symptoms. The patient's family history of major depressive disorder and suicide also supports this diagnosis.
